title: Dual-screen smartphones with quirks
text:

Image 1 of 4 Image 2 of 4 Image 3 of 4 Image 4 of 4 Dual-screen smartphones with quirks 1  /  4 Back to Gallery Samsung Galaxy S6 Edge+ 
Cnet rating: 4.5 stars out of 5 (Outstanding)
The good: It has a compelling design, top-tier specs and excellent battery life. Its second menu for the curved display adds some useful shortcuts.
The bad: The usefulness doesn’t live up to its sky-high price. Fans of removable batteries and microSD card slots will be disappointed that this has neither.
The cost: $450 (with two-year contract) to $900
The bottom line: Buy the Edge+ if you love the idea of a wraparound screen; otherwise, you’ll find less expensive phones that do nearly as much.
Samsung Continuum 
Cnet rating: 3.5 stars out of 5 (Very good)
The good: It features two displays; the smaller ticker window is a great tool for quickly accessing information and multitasking. The smartphone also has a 1GHz processor and a 5-megapixel camera with HD video capture. It offers full wireless options and can be used as a mobile hot spot.
The bad: The smaller screen makes for more cramped typing. Ticker display isn’t available for third-party apps. Runs Android 2.1, and Bing is the default search engine. You can’t uninstall preloaded apps and services.
The cost: $25 to $100
The bottom line: More than just a gimmick, the Continuum’s secondary display is a useful management and multitasking tool, but its constant flow of information might not appeal to everybody.
Kyocera Echo 
Cnet rating: 3.5 stars out of 5 (Very good) 
The good: Its one-of-kind design offers two screens and the ability to use two applications at once. Call quality is acceptable, and the phone is quick and responsive.
The bad: The design entails some usability quirks, and we’re concerned about long-term durability. The feature set is pretty average, it lacks 4G, and you’ll have to wait for an upgrade beyond Froyo.
The cost: $128
The bottom line: The design offers some unique advantages, but its appeal is hampered by usability quirks and lackluster features.
LG Doubleplay 
Cnet rating: 3.5 stars out of 5 (Very good)
The good: It has a vibrant and sharp display, a 1GHz Qualcomm Scorpion processor, Android 2.3 Gingerbread, DLNA support, Wi-Fi calling, mobile hotspot support, full Webkit browser with Adobe Flash, support for T-Mobile ’s 4G/HSPA+ network, a 5-megapixel camera with 720p HD video capture, and great call quality.
The bad: The quirky dual screen and split keyboard design is a little too strange for us. It’s a hefty and bulky handset, and has poor battery life.
The cost: $200
The bottom line: It has excellent features for a midrange Android smartphone, but its bizarre design is not for everyone.
Cnet staff contributing to this story are Bonnie Cha, Jessica Dolcourt, Kent German, Nicole Lee and Laura K. Cucullu . For more reviews of personal technology products, visit www.cnet.com.
